results.title: The Environment (NP)
results.creator_credit: Ashley Schwall-Kearney, Craig Saunders, ABC-TV (Australia), Monash University and Open Learning Agency of Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode number 12 of Series “The Global Economy”.
This episode of the Open Learning Economics course looks at the way the international economic community is tackling the issue of environmental protection. Since the late 1970s there has been a growing concern, especially by communities in wealthier nations, over the high environmental cost of unrestricted economic development. Developing countries, however, have argued that trade restrictions predicated on environmental law offer unfair economic advantages to richer nations. In the first half of the program we look at the example of the Mexican tuna industry which has come under fire because of the destruction of dolphin life. However when the United States attempted to place an embargo on Mexican tuna, the General Agreement on Tarrifs and Trade (GATT) ruled that this was contrary to the principles of Free Trade. In the second half we look at the destruction of Europe’s Rhine River by industrial pollution. The panel of economists examining both issues discuss some of the implications for trade if environmental law becomes institutionalised in the global economy.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ashley Schwall-Kearney, Craig Saunders, ABC-TV (Australia), Monash University and Open Learning Agency of Australia

results.title: Economies in transition (NP)
results.creator_credit: Ashley Schwall-Kearney, Craig Saunders, ABC-TV (Australia), Monash University and Open Learning Agency of Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode number 11 of Series “The Global Economy”.
This episode of the Open Learning Economics course examines the development of free market economic systems in the former communist states of Eastern Europe. The first episode looks at the emergence of liberal capitalism in Russia. The episode examines the benefits of opening Russia’s markets to the rest of the globe though it acknowledges that this embracement of capitalism, at an accelerated pace, has the potential to create devastating divisions based on wealth. The second episode looks at the success of capitalism in Poland which turned away from State Socialism in the early 1980s. In interviews with economists and Polish business people we are given an insight into some of the difficulties involved in dismantling a socialist economic system and replacing it with a market open to the international capitalist economy.

results.title: Doctor De Soto and 5 other funny stories
results.creator_credit: Michael Sporn, Morton Schindel and Weston Woods Studios
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Children’s circle”.
A collection of animated short stories for children. “Doctor De Soto” by William Steig. The kind-hearted mouse Doctor De Soto is a dentist. He and his wife find a very clever way to treat a crafty fox, who comes to them with a sore tooth and secret thoughts of eating them after the job is done. This outstanding cartoon was nominated for an Academy Award for Best Animated Short Film. “Patrick” by Quentin Blake. When Patrick plays his fiddle, the countryside comes alive with vibrant colour and motion. “The Hat” by Tomi Ungerer. Penniless Benito finds good fortune when he comes upon a magic black hat with which he can perform fantastic feats. “Smile for Auntie” by Diane Paterson. Silly Auntie sings, dances, makes funny faces, stands on her head - anything to get the baby to smile! “The Foolish Frog” by Pete And Charles Seeger. Folk singer Pete Seeger plays and sings this catchy song about the frog who fell in the mud, to the delightful drawings of Mioslav Jagr. “Leopold the See-through Crumb-picker” by James Flora. Leopold is invisible and devours every crumb he finds, creating havoc in the process. See what happens when a little girl befriends him.

results.title: Where the wild things are and 5 other stories
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Children’s circle”.
Where the wild things are is Maurice Sendak’s classic tale of Mischievous Max, who sails to where the wild things are and becomes their king. “The Nutshell Kids” features four delightful teaching poems set to music. “In the Night Kitchen” Little Mickey dreams of the kitchen at night where bakers bake cakes, dough aeroplanes fly and everyone dances to the deliciously syncopated music.

results.title: Asterix in Britain
results.creator_credit: Pino Van Lamsweerde, Yannik Piel, Dargaud Films and Gaumont-British Instructional
results.brief_description: The world-famous comic-strip character, that madcap Gaul, Asterix is brought to life in this animated feature. The battle skills of the Britons are undeniably the equal of Caesar’s Roman troops. However, they are handicapped by their habit of refusing to fight on weekends and leaving the battlefield promptly at five every afternoon in time for tea. Whilst the Britons are caught napping after dinner, the Romans win the war and overrun Britain. A plea from the English leader, Zebigboss, goes out to the mighty Asterix and his Roman-hating friend Obelix. Join all the familiar friends in this great adventure including Druid Getafix, Dogmatix, Chief Vitalstatistix, Cacofonix and many more. Based on the popular books by Goscinny and Underzo.

results.title: Madeline's Christmas
results.creator_credit: Stephen Martiniere, Ronald A Weinberg, Cinar and France Animation
results.brief_description: Madeline (the mischievous little heroine with a heart twice her size) and eleven of her friends experience a snowstorm and are confined indoors. But it’s Christmas so Madeline cares and cleans for her sneezing friends with many songs and cheer, reminding us all of the true spirit of Christmas - love and friendship. Based on the popular novels by Ludwig Bemelmans and narrated by Christopher Plummer.

results.title: My little chickadee
results.brief_description: Mae West is teamed with W.C. Fields in this classic comedy filled with Wild West action and lusty humour. The familiar Westian swagger, drawl, wisecracks and innuendos are all included, likewise the typical Field’s routines and quick-triggered comments. The pairing of the two stars was at the time considered to ensure a box-office success, but it would see sparks fly with the clashing of two great super-egos. However a West-Fields non-aggression pact was inspired in part by the fact that the two players wrote their own screen story. Scenes in which the pair work together are reduced to a minimum with the script set up being a continual series of episodes, first with West and then with Fields. The story is simple; Flower Belle Lee, returning from a complete course in a Chicago dance hall, has a way with men. A masked bandit falls in love with her, which eventually leads to her being drummed out of town. Meeting Cuthbert J. Twillie on the train on the way out, she believes him to have money, and promotes a fake wedding ceremony. The pair hit the next fronteir settlement, where Twillie becomes the sherrif, and West tosses her charms around rather freely.

results.title: Aladdin
results.creator_credit: John Musker, Ron Clements and Walt Disney Pictures
results.brief_description: Soar away on a magic carpet ride of non-stop enchantment in the most spectacular animated adventure of all time. Outrageously funny, furiously fast-paced and packed with dazzling surprises this film won two Academy Awards for Best Song (‘A Whole new world’) and for Best Score. Follow the fantastic story of Aladdin, a street-smart peasant boy who, with one rub of a magic lamp, meets up with the most hip, hilarious, totally unpredictable Genie the screen has ever seen. But the evil sorcerer, Jafar, also craves the lamp’s power. If Aladdin is to defeat him and win the love of the free spirited Jasmine, he must learn to be himself - and that’s one wish the Genie can’t grant! Now enjoy the breathtaking Disney artistry and phenomenal fun. Robin Williams is hilarious as the voice of the Genie. Voices also include Scott Weinger, Linda Larkin, Jonathan Freeman, Frank Welker.

results.title: Sky trackers
results.creator_credit: John Power, Anthony Buckley and Australian Children's Television Foundation
results.brief_description: It started as innocent fun and turned into an adventure of galactic proportions! Ali (Maia Brewton) lives on a NASA Satellite Tracking Station where her Mum (Pamela Sue Martin) works as a space scientist. A computer whiz, Ali spends her spare time hacking into the station’s mainframe to record her personal diary. One evening while hacking into the computer she discovers a runaway satellite is out of control and heading straight for Earth and is likely to crash nearby. What she doesn’t know is that the satellite contains a load of deadly cargo, so dangerous it threatens the safety of the entire world…

A computer whiz, Ali spends her spare time hacking into the station’s mainframe to record her personal diary. One evening while hacking into the computer she discovers a runaway satellite is out of control and heading straight for Earth and is likely to crash nearby. What she doesn’t know is that the satellite contains a load of deadly cargo, so dangerous it threatens the safety of the entire world…
description_for_label: It started as innocent fun and turned into an adventure of galactic proportions! Ali (Maia Brewton) lives on a NASA Satellite Tracking Station where her Mum (Pamela Sue Martin) works as a space scientist. A computer whiz, Ali spends her spare time hacking into the station’s mainframe to record her personal diary. One evening while hacking into the computer she discovers a runaway satellite is out of control and heading straight for Earth and is likely to crash nearby. What she doesn’t know is that the satellite contains a load of deadly cargo, so dangerous it threatens the safety of the entire world…

creators_other.name: Victorian Council for Children's Films and Television

results.title: Blood sweat and tears. Vol. 4
results.creator_credit: Denny Lawrence, Frank Seres and Frank Seres Productions
results.brief_description: Narrated by Chris Haywood, this final volume of the series “Blood sweat and tears: Australians and sport” includes the episodes: “Bought sport” investigates the issues surrounding commercial sponsorship of sport, both amatuer and professional and asks the question - if sport was supposed to be the great equaliser, spreading ideals about manliness, team spirit and fair play, and with so much money riding on a win, have the ideals of sport been corrupted? “Political football” looks at the issues of how politics influence sport - athletes have long complained about victimisation by sporting bureaucrats. Sport and politics don’t mix and can sport, realistically, be amoral? “Wearing the green and gold” focuses on why Australian athletes feel they must achieve recognition in the world sporting arena in order to feel they have succeeded in their chosen field. Why isn’t reaching the pinnacle of your chosen sport in Australia enough?
results.creator_credit_for_label: Denny Lawrence, Frank Seres and Frank Seres Productions
